Problem:
Consider a continuous function \\( h(x) \\) defined on real numbers, and its Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(h)(\\omega) \\). Analyze the scenario where modification is performed by another function \\( p(x) = e^{-ax^2} \\) where \\( a > 0 \\) is a constant.

If \\( p(x) \\) modifies the function \\( h(x) \\) at \\( t = 0 \\) to form a new function \\( q(x) = p(x)h(x) \\), and then its Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(q)(\\omega) \\) is taken, will the transformed result directly correspond to the Fourier transform of \\( h(x) \\) multiplied by the Fourier transform of \\( p(x) \\)?
Explanation: According to the convolution theorem in Fourier analysis, the Fourier transform of the product of two functions, in this case \\( q(x) = p(x)h(x) \\), equals the convolution of their individual Fourier transforms. Given that \\( p(x) \\) is a Gaussian function, its Fourier transform is also a Gaussian, hence \\( \\mathcal{F}(q)(\\omega) \\) results from convoluting \\( \\mathcal{F}(h)(\\omega) \\) with a Gaussian, not just a simple multiplication.
